newsitem.title: USA: Chrysler car and light truck sales seen strong in August.
newsitem.headline: Chrysler car and light truck sales seen strong in August.

text.p: Buyers continued to snap up Chrysler Corp.'s minivans and pickup trucks in August, which should lead the No. 3 automaker to another double-digit increase in monthly sales results, analysts said Friday.

General Motors Corp., which had strong passenger car sales a year ago, has been telling analysts its sales will come in under those of August 1995. Ford Motor Co.'s sales will be unchanged to slightly below year-ago levels as light trucks again outpace car sales.

Results from GM and Ford are expected to drag down the light vehicle sales total on a daily selling basis. But most analysts expect the seasonally adjusted selling rate to finish in the healthy mid-15 million range.

"Overall, I think the SAAR (seasonally adjusted annual rate) will look fine," said Mike Luckey, president of Luckey Consulting Group. "The daily rate will be down a little bit, but I don't think it's anything to get alarmed about because you're up against a strong month last year."
The seasonal rate is computed using factors from the Commerce Department. The July rate was 14.3 million units.
Last year, August sales ran at a 15.7 million seasonal rate, the second-highest of calendar 1995.
"It sounds to me like a mixed month," said John Casesa, an analyst with Schroder Wertheim.

Chrysler, the only one of the Detroit's Big Three with a four-door minivan, continues to benefit from the popularity of those vehicles. But its total light truck percentage increase from August 1995 will be helped by exceptionally low numbers a year ago, when a model changeover held down production of minivans and Ram pickups.

Chrysler announced Thursday that it sold 2,189,420 vehicles in the first 11 months of the 1996 model year ending Aug. 28. That beats the previous record for a full model year -- Oct. 1 through Sept. 30 -- of 2,186,128 units.

Analysts predict Japanese automakers will have a big month in August. Toyota Motor Corp. typically uses the month to launch aggressive late model-year inventory clear-outs. Honda Motor Co. Ltd. also pushes retail sales in August.
Strong sales of the Honda Accord sedan could pose a problem for the Ford Taurus, which is battling to stay ahead of the Accord in the race for the best-selling car in the United States for 1996.
Chrysler is scheduled to report sales Sept. 3 and GM will report Sept. 4. Ford and Toyota are expected to announce their sales results Sept. 5.
